ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about how to give feedback to other scholars while they're presenting their papers, how to frame comments and questions, etc. I was introduced to Marcel Mauss, who I'd never really studied before.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think the strength of this workshop is that it sets a high expectation for attendance for junior fellows. I really appreciate that. However, I think the actual engagement of the fellows should be increased. Some people come and say a lot, while others come and say nothing. And sometimes I gave feedback to the scholar presenting, and wished there was an avenue by which to receive feedback on *my* feedback, so that I can get better at that kind of interaction. I also wish that there was more opportunity for interaction throughout the semester with other junior fellows and faculty fellows, visiting scholars, etc. to get to know each other better, like the supper club or other events. Sometimes I think that the emphasis on the strong program could be made a bit more. Some of the scholars who came to visit, it seemed like they didn't understand the strong program or the format of the workshop.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would definitely recommend this course.
